For some strange reason I expect this to be interpretted by the liberals as a dead heat.

For some strange reason I expect this to be interpretted by the liberals as a dead heat.

 
 What some "brainiacs" have been saying is that given the margin of error of +/- 4%, this is a statistical dead heat, when it really isn't.
 
 If Bush were ahead by 4% then it would statistically be a dead heat, but Bush being ahead by 8% in this poll puts him ahead of Kerry outside the margin of error.
 
 Kerry is fading. Kerry will lose.

 Jim, if it makes you feel better, why don't we just say Bush leads Kerry and leave it at that? Technically, with the 4 pt. margin of error, it is a dead heat: Bush could be overstated by 4 and Kerry understated by 4, which would make them even. The truth is, Bush is probably leading by some margin, whatever it may be. It's not about being Liberal, it's about understanding mathmatics, something this administration has a problem with when trying to stay within their budget.

 I have no problem understanding the math here. I just figured someone from the liberal side would take advantage of the margins of error in both figures and say that it's a dead heat. Somebody did.
 
 Like you, I doubt the error was in Kerry's favor on both counts.
 
 I don't really care that much who's ahead in these polls. It's the Election Day polls that count. (I didn't start this thread...Traveler beat me to it.)
 
 ...

I'm not making any predictions based on polls. What with the battleground states and the millions of newly registered, etc. anything could happen.
 
 But I have been thinking lately that if Bush wins, it could be for the best. I'd rather he was in office when it happens again -- since he's so sure that it will happen again. GWB is so fond of saying that we have to be right 100% and they only need once. He's already hedging his bet.
